items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has six (19) pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment that the District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined are obsolete and of no further use to the District. In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers. Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olage, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 2. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that is not satisfactory for further use by the District. California Education Code sections 81450 – 81452 provide that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use. The estimated aggregate resale value is greater than $5,000.00.
	 
District staff will assess and identify the most efficient manner to disposition the surplus that is in the best interest of the District and in accordance with California Education Code.
 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to arrange for the sale, donation, recycle, or disposal of the surplus in accordance with the procedures set forth in Education Code sections 81450-81452.
items.item_text: Sell, Donate, Recycle or Dispose of District Surplus
items.item_text_raw: 3. Sell, Donate, Recycle or Dispose of District Surplus

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Resource 25 is a room and scheduling software actively used by Foothill and De Anza scheduling offices since 2002 to support and assist with some of the core scheduling functions and tasks, such as quarterly class schedule production, room usage and utilization reports, building renovation and maintenance, room features and inventory, and room reservation for office hours and class related events.  Resource 25 is also utilized by the Facilities Office to do room booking for student clubs and events and room rental for external organizations. 
	 
Resource 25 is a licensed software with a recurring annual cost of $10,660 that is split 60-40 between De Anza and Foothill colleges.  The hardware for the application was purchased by the colleges with technical support, maintenance, and platform upgrades provided from Educational Technology Services (ETS). Both colleges are running on an outdated version of Resource 25 software on aging hardware.  The system needs to be upgraded to ensure proper system performance and functionality. 
	 
Recently, CollegeNet made significant investments to move the Resource 25 application from an on-premise solution to a hosted solution ("cloud" solution). This change eliminates many processes both colleges and ETS need to do in our local data center. We will no longer provide the hardware or maintenance to run the system. The application will be running from a site hosted by CollegeNet.
	 
Consequently, both colleges asked ETS to upgrade the current system to the new hosted solution. This will require the District to sign a new contract with CollegeNet. This solution guarantees the District will always have up-to-date scheduling software and hardware and a powerful and robust scheduling system to meet the needs of the scheduling and facilities offices and other Foothill-De Anza staff, faculty, and students.
	 
The breakdown of one-time and recurring cost of the new contract is:
					 
One time cost
Recurring hosting cost per year
Total 3-year cost
Professional service and training*
$26,000*
 0.00
$26,000
One time license fee
$26,000
					 
$26,000
Recurring cost
					 
$25,000
$75,000
Total 3-year cost
					 
					 
$127,000* 
 *includes two one-week on-site consultation visits. Travel expenses estimated at $5,000 for both trips, and are included in the cost calculation.
	 
Submitted by:
Joseph Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Systems & Operations, x 6139
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On November 4, 2015, the De Anza Associated Student Body Senate (DASB) voted (second time) to reconfirm an increase to the DASB membership fee from $9 to $10 per quarter, effective with the 2016-2017 fiscal year. This increase would be effective beginning 2016 summer quarter. Membership fees were last increased from $6 to $9 during the academic year 2011-2012. This proposed increase is needed to cover inflationary costs for many of the traditionally funded DASB/college programs, in addition to funding new programs since 2012. DASB has experienced: (1) a decline in Flea Market income, and (2) a leveling of income from membership fees.This has resulted in the need to identify new funding sources. The current ASFC is $10 per quarter so this increase brings parity with our sister college.
	 
Submitted by:
 De Anza College Acting President Christina Espinosa-Pieb, ext. 8958
Additional contact names:
 VP, Student Services, Stacey Cook, ext. 8330; Michele Lebleu-Burns, ext. 8218
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College Acting President Christina Espinosa-Pieb recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Gene Haas Foundation (“the foundation”) and De Anza College faculty and administration have been working on a proposed gift from the foundation of
$1 million for De Anza College to expand the college’s Design and Manufacturing Technologies facilities.  This proposal includes a naming opportunity for the NAME OF THE BUILDING NEEDS TO BE HERE  Per board policy, the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees is required to approve any proposed naming opportunity for a district facility.
	 
This matter has been referred to the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees with a favorable recommendation from Chancellor Judy Miner and De Anza College President Brian Murphy.  Furthermore, on or about November 11, 2015, the board of trustees of the Gene Haas Foundation approved the $1 million gift request.
	 
Recommended Action: Acceptance of the $1 million capital gift and approval of the naming request, “Haas Center for Advanced Manufacturing."
	 
Project Overview: (Total estimated cost $950,000)  Expand classroom E23 of existing E2 building into CNC lab and E25, a 30- seat lecture classroom into 30-seat lecture / computer lab. Additional labs will assist with increased training space for five more CNC machines (15 total); increased inspection area adding one more CMM (3 total); and 30 computer seats (122 total). The labs will be used for CAD/CAM programming and simulation courses.  The proposed expansion project is estimated to be $800,000; additional tooling and fixtures for machines and inspection area estimated to be $150,000.
	 
De Anza Design and Manufacturing Technologies:  The Design and Manufacturing Technologies department contains some of the nation’s leading programs.  It is NIMS accredited in machining, and it offers approximately 35 courses in CAD, CAM, CNC mill and lathe properties of materials and blueprint interpretation, among others.  The courses are offered in accelerated six week (four days per week), evening twelve week (two nights per week), Saturday and on-line classes.
	 
With an annual enrollment of more than 1,500 students, the department offers four certificates and three A.S. degrees.   The department has a robust advisory council, including participation from NASA, Apple, Google, Intuitive Surgical, Northrup Grumman and Tesla Motors.
	 
In 2015, De Anza offered summer teacher training courses, filling its classes to capacity with high school and community college instructors from throughout the state.  The program, with help from the Gene Haas Foundation, will continue to expand its offerings.  The department also trains apprentices for the California Machinist & Tooling Apprenticeship Association and Machinist Joint Apprenticeship Committee.  Moreover, the department has longstanding relationships with equipment manufacturers and industry, including a deep relationship with Haas Automation, Inc., as well as with the Gene Haas Foundation.
	 
FHDA Policy on the Naming of Facilities:  Board policy and administrative procedure 3216 provide criteria for naming that involves a gift, as in this case.  Those include:
	 
·      The significance of the proposed gift as it relates to the project;
·      The urgency of need for the project or for support funds for the project;
·      The eminence, reputation and integrity of the individual or entity whose name is proposed; and
·      The relationship of the individual or entity to the colleges or District.
	 
In addition, the district’s procedures require that the gift constitute a significant portion of the total cost of the project to be named.
	 
With regard to the criteria, a $1 million gift from the foundation would construct the entire project (as outlined above).  Although the need/construction of the project is not urgent, the opportunity to secure this possible gift is urgent as the foundation is interested in granting such a gift to a community college by the end of the calendar year due in large part to the incredibly strong relationship that De Anza College and its staff have with the foundation (and with Haas Automation, Inc.). 
	 
Also related to the district’s criteria, it should be noted that in 2007, Mr. Gene Haas was convicted of federal tax evasion and was required to serve two years in federal prison and pay $75 million in restitution to the federal government.  His jail time was completed and the required restitution was paid, as ordered, and the conviction was not tied to the Gene Haas Foundation or its grantees.  The foundation continues to be a leader in philanthropy around the nation in the areas of advanced manufacturing, teacher training and food security.
	 
History of the Gene Haas Foundation:  The Gene Haas Foundation, in Oxnard, California, was founded in 1998 by Gene Francis Haas, founder, president and sole stockholder of Haas Automation, Inc., one of the world's leading CNC (Computer Numerical Controlled) machine tool manufacturers.  The foundation gives primarily to children's charities and organizations that feed the poor, especially within the local community of Ventura County.  It also gives to scholarship funds to high schools, community colleges and special educational programs that help build skills within the machining industry.
	 
In September, the Gene Haas Foundation announced a $1 million capital gift to New York’s Hudson Valley Community College as part of the college’s $12 million technology center expansion.  And, on November 4, 2015, the National Institute of Metalworking Skills (NIMS) officially opened the Gene Haas Education Center, located on its campus in Fairfax, Virginia.  This new education center was created to help educators and businesses deliver the highest quality and most relevant manufacturing training for students and employees.  (De Anza College is only one of a few colleges in California that are NIMS accredited.)
	 
To date, more than 1,200 charitable organizations and schools have received more than $27 million from the Gene Haas Foundation.
	 
·      Foundation assets as of December 2013:  $94.5 million
·      Total giving in 2013:  $3.1 million
·      Website:  http://ghaasfoundation.org/
	 
Submitted by:
De Anza College President Brian Murphy
Additional contact names:
Foothill-De Anza Foundation Director of Development Dennis Cima
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Acceptance of the $1 million capital gift and approval of the naming request, “Haas Center for Advanced Manufacturing."

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The development of the Student Equity Plan for 2015-16 was based on input from multiple college groups and has been a continuation of the work done for the 2014-15 Plan.  The tri-chairs of the 3SP Advisory Committee, the Basic Skills Workgroup, and the Student Equity Workgroup as well as the Vice President of Instruction, Associate Vice President of Instruction, and Institutional Researcher met several times during the Summer of 2015 to identify areas of common interest and collaboratively develop strategies to best utilize human and financial resources to increase student success.   After continued discussion by the Student Equity Workgroup, the equity plan was approved by PaRC in November 2015.
	 
The Foothill College Student Equity Plan supports five overarching activities:
Creation of a Student Success and Retention Team with members from both student services and instruction to provide both operational support and program coordination to our equity activities.
Development of an Early Alert System that integrates Student Services and Instruction to provide student engagement and support for a variety of needs.
Development of a Mentoring Program that includes faculty and staff as well as peer to peer mentoring and is integrated with the Early Alert System.
Provision of Professional Development that is action-oriented to provide support for change as well as support for practical and tangible activities to better serve and support disproportionately impacted students.
Application of a robust Research Agenda to provide faculty and staff data showing the most productive ways to help our students.
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Foothill College, Interim President
Additional contact names:
Andrew LaManque, Kurt Hueg
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College Administration recommends that the Board of Trustees approve the Foothill College Student Equity Plan.
items.item_text: Foothill College Student Equity Plan (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 10. Foothill College Student Equity Plan (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Student Equity-Student Success Support Program Advisory Committee, which has broad college representation, began working on the 2015-2016 equity plan in August 2015. The work group reviewed the recommendations made by the Chancellor's Office on the 2014-2015 plan and updated data disaggregated by various subpopulations to identify where outcomes indicated that some groups were disproportionately impacted compared to others. They then identified high impact practices aimed at reducing differences in outcomes.
	 
The De Anza College Equity Plan was approved by the Planning and Budget Teams and Campus Budget in Fall 2015.
	 
Submitted by:
 De Anza Acting President, Christina Espinosa-Pieb, ext. 8958
Additional contact names:
 AVP Instruction & Student Services, Rowena Tomaneng, ext 8510, Rob Mieso, ext 8835, and Veronica Neal, Director, Office of Equity, Social Justice and Multicultural Education ext. 5338
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Acting President Christina Espinosa-Pieb recommends approval of the 2015 De Anza College Student Equity Plan.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Due to the increase to the California minimum wage to $10.00 on 1/1/16, the following salary schedule is proposed to be effective 1/1/16:
	 
                  Step 1   Step 2
Level I      $10.00   $10.75       entry/trainee level
Level II     $12.00   $12.75       intermediate level
Level III    $14.00   $14.75       specialist level
Level IV    $16.00   $16.75       technical/specialized  level 
	 
Both Foothill and De Anza Student Employment Administrators are in favor of the increase to all four levels and their subsequent raise amount.  The last increase to the entire salary schedule was effective 1/1/2007 with the last schedule increase on 7/1/2014 for only Level I, step 1 & 2.
	 
For reference, the current salary schedule is:
	 
                Step 1   Step 2
Level I     $9.00    $9.75
Level II    $10.00  $10.75
Level III   $12.00  $12.75
Level IV   $14.00  $14.75
	 
See except of CA.GOV website (http://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/FAQ_MinimumWage.htm) for verification of January 1st requirement:
	 
Minimum Wage
	 
Although there are some exceptions, almost all employees in California must be paid the minimum wage as required by state law. Effective July 1, 2014, the minimum wage in California is $9.00 per hour. Effective January 1, 2016, the minimum wage in California is $10.00 per hour. There are some employees who are exempt from the minimum wage law, such as outside salespersons, individuals who are the parent, spouse, or child of the employer, and apprentices regularly indentured under the State Division of Apprenticeship Standards.
Minimum Wage Order (MW-2014)
	 
There is an exception for learners, regardless of age, who may be paid not less than 85% of the minimum wage rounded to the nearest nickel during their first 160 hours of employment in occupations in which they have no previous similar or related experience.
	 
There are also exceptions for employees who are mentally or physically disabled, or both, and for nonprofit organizations such as sheltered workshops or rehabilitation facilities that employ disabled workers. Such individuals and organizations may be issued a special license by the Division of Labor Standards Enforcement authorizing employment at a wage less than the legal minimum wage. Labor Code Sections 1191 and 1191.5
	 
1. Q. What is the minimum wage?
	A. Effective January 1, 2008, the minimum wage in California is $8.00 per hour. It will increase to $9.00 per hour effective July 1, 2014, and to $10.00 per hour effective January 1, 2016.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President, Foothill College, and Brian Murphy, President, De Anza College
Additional contact names:
Denise Swett, Kevin Harral, Stacey Cook, Lisa Mandy
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College and De Anza College administration recommend the Board of Trustees approve the student salary schedule.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis.  In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s investments as of September 30, 2015.
	 
The District’s cash, in the amount of $176,768,162.06, is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool.  As of on September 30, 2015, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.68%.  As a comparison to the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.63%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.07%; and the State of California Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.33%.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In compliance with the California Community Colleges Budget and Accounting Manual, the Board is presented with a list of existing bank accounts for review and confirmation.  The list of bank accounts includes the position titles of those individuals authorized as signers on these accounts.
	 
In 2015, the County of Santa Clara issued a Request for Proposal (RFP) for banking services. Wells Fargo Bank was selected as the finalist to replace Bank of America, effective December 1, 2015.  The District finalized its testing of warrants, ACH files, and account reconcilement files in November 2015 for the three main County banking accounts, account 9667451570, 4570497545, and 4570827618, as presented in Resolution No. 2015-31.  The District expects to move the remaining accounts that it holds at Bank of America to Wells Fargo Bank by March 31, 2016. 
	 
A resolution to authorize separate bank accounts and to authorize the signers of these accounts, by position, is presented to the Board for adoption.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board adopt Resolution No. 2015-31 Authorizing Separate Bank Accounts.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District currently offers two deferred compensation plans under Internal Revenue Code Section 457(b). The first plan is administered by Valic; the second plan is administered by the Employee Benefits Services Group.  The two deferred compensation plans were selected based on Request for Proposal (RFP) No. 1464 which was issued on January 19, 2012.
	 
The CalSTRS Pension2 457 Deferred Compensation Plan was not selected; however, it was a close runner up with the Employee Benefits Services Group 457 Deferred Compensation Plan.  A committee (composed of administrators and representatives from the various bargaining units) reviewed the RFP responses and made the final recommendation to select only two 457 deferred compensation plans, until such time as the District could evaluate the two plans and determine administratively the extent to which it could add a third plan.  Upon further review and discussion with this same committee, the District staff are confident that we can administer a third deferred compensation plan, as offered by CalSTRS.
	 
Staff recommend adding the CalSTRS Pension2 457 Deferred Compensation Plan as a third deferred compensation plan for the benefit of our employees.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board adopt Resolution No. 2015-34 Authorizing the Adoption of the CalSTRS Pension2 457 Deferred Compensation Plan.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This action is in response to the decision by CalPERS Board of Administration regarding Appeal of the denial of coverage for the District’s “20-Year Retirees” under the District’s contract with CalPERS Health. This action requests authority to draft changes to the 401(a) Plan (the “Plan”), file an IRS determination letter application for the amended Plan, and delegation of authority to adopt technical changes to the Plan required to obtain a favorable IRS determination letter. 
	 
The Board of Trustees is being asked to consider and approve a Resolution to adopt an amendment to the Plan to limit participation to qualified former members of the Board of Trustees following a finding by an Administrative Law Judge and confirmation by the CalPERS Board of Administration that participation in the Plan by retired employees under the status of 20-Year Retiree would not qualify such retirees for coverage under the CalPERS retiree health program.  In addition, in accordance with CalPERS requirements, the Plan will be submitted to the IRS for a determination on its tax-qualified status prior to January 31, 2016. The Board of Trustees also is requested to delegate authority to make any technical changes to the Plan required to obtain the favorable determination from the IRS.  
	 
1.         Amendment to 401(a) Plan
	 
A.        Background
	 
In 2012, the District contracted with CalPERS to provide health coverage for current and former employees who are eligible for District-provided health benefits under the Public Employees Medical and Hospital Care Act ("PEMHCA").  At that time, there was a concern that certain former employees who qualify for lifetime retiree health benefits under one of the District's collective bargaining agreements would not meet the PEMHCA eligibility rules for retiree coverage, because they were not receiving a monthly retirement allowance, i.e., an annuity.  The Board adopted the Plan to address this concern.  The Plan is a supplemental retirement plan that provides a monthly retirement allowance to former employees who are not yet retired under CalPERS or CalSTRS, and to former members of the Board of Trustees, who qualify for District-provided lifetime retiree health benefits.
	 
CalPERS officials denied PEMHCA eligibility for former District retirees who were covered under the Plan, but were not retired under CalPERS or CalSTRS.  However, CalPERS officials decided that former members of the Board of Trustees are eligible for PEMHCA coverage on the basis of receiving a retirement allowance from the Plan.
	 
The District's appeal of the CalPERS decision with respect to former employees was heard in March of this year by an Administrative Law Judge, who denied the appeal in a proposed decision that was adopted as final by the CalPERS Board of Administration at its meeting on November 18, 2015.  This means that the Plan will not serve the purpose of enabling certain former employees to meet the PEMHCA eligibility requirements for retiree coverage, so participation for these former employees should be terminated.
	 
B.        Plan Amendment
	 
Accordingly, we propose that the Plan be amended to cover only qualified former members of the Board of Trustees, effective January 1, 2016.  A Board Resolution and Plan Amendment for this purpose are attached.
	 
2.         IRS Determination Letter Application
	 
The Plan is intended to qualify for tax-favored status under section 401 and related sections of the Internal Revenue Code.  In addition, CalPERS rules require that this type of retirement plan obtain a favorable IRS determination letter.  The District will apply to the IRS for a favorable determination letter on the Plan's tax-qualified status before January 31, 2016, the current deadline for IRS filings for governmental plans such as the Plan. We also are proposing that the Board of Trustees delegate authority to adopt any technical amendments that may be required in order to obtain a favorable determination letter from the IRS.  
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Adoption of resolution 2015-33.
items.item_text: Resolution Amending the Foothill-De Anza Community College District 401(a) Retirement Plan Covering Trustees and 20-Year Retirees (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 18. Resolution Amending the Foothill-De Anza Community College District 401(a) Retirement Plan Covering Trustees and 20-Year Retirees (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District requires complete and comprehensive turnkey services to collect, package, manifest, dispose of, and transport various hazardous liquid and solid waste from its campuses to designated and EPA approved permitted waste facilities. These services are required to meet the District’s desire to support a hierarchy of waste disposal that promotes recycling and reuse, and also state and federal reporting requirements and laws (including those of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Dept. of Environmental Health, the Fire Departments and the local Sanitary districts).  
					 
Therefore, District staff developed a Request for Proposal (RFP) for the required services to dispose of chemical (non-bioharzardous) and universal hazardous waste from both campuses and eventually the Education Center in Sunnyvale.  The awarding vendor must  be a properly licensed hazardous waste collection, transportation, packaging, manifesting, and disposal company and is required to profile all waste prior to acceptance into a permitted facility as well as generate electronic reports that meet the Districts’ state and locally mandated reporting requirements. The RFP also requires the vendor to provide emergency hazardous waste response and remediation and decontamination /cleaning services if, or when, necessary.   
					 
RFP #1739 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on October 6 and October 13, 2015 and notification of the RFP was also broadcasted through FHDA’s Purchasing web page. Additionally, Purchasing Services staff reached out to local vendors who provide these services to notify each of them of this opportunity. Proposals were due on November 12, 2015 and the following six vendors submitted responses:
Advanced Chemical Transport, Inc.
Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc.
HCI Environmental & Engineering Service
Heritage Environmental Services, LLC
Stericycle Environmental Solutions
Veolia Environmental Services Technical Solutions, LLC 
Ms. Karen Lauricella –Director of Environmental Health & Safety and Purchasing Services staff reviewed and evaluated the proposals.  They were evaluated based upon five primary criteria, including qualifications (expertise/approach and proposed team members), safety, and fees.  The firm that ranked the highest overall score is Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. (Clean Harbors).
	 
District staff recommends that the Board of Trustees authorize a 30-month contract with Clean Harbors for the described Hazardous Waste program services at an estimated cost of $150,000 per year valid through June 30, 2018.  The District has an option to renew the contract for an additional 30-month term for a maximum of five years total. The Hazardous Waste regular and routine program services will be paid for with Environmental Health and Safety General Fund. 
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services - x6166
Additional contact names:
  Karen Lauricella - x6146, Gina Bailey - x6165
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Director of Purchasing Services Pam Grey to enter into a 30-month contract with Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. for Hazardous Waste Collection, Packaging, Transportation, and Disposal Program Services based upon the general scope of services and pricing structures provided in RFP #1739.
items.item_text: Award a Contract Pursuant to Request for Proposal #1739 – Hazardous Waste Collection, Packaging, Transportation, and Disposal Program Services (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 19. Award a Contract Pursuant to Request for Proposal #1739 – Hazardous Waste Collection, Packaging, Transportation, and Disposal Program Services (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On November 5, 2012, the board approved a consignment agreement for Okuma equipment with Gosiger West. The consignment agreement has expired and the De Anza College Design and Manufacturing Technology (DMT) program would like to purchase the consigned equipment. The equipment has been incorporated into the DMT program’s advanced curriculum and instruction.
	 
The purchase of the consigned equipment will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000. If the District were to prepare a bid specification for a used live tooling Y-axis machine meeting all of the requirements of the DMT department, only Gosiger West would be able to submit a bid. Gosiger West is the only vendor who is qualified to sell this consigned equipment to the college.  
	 
The Okuma LB3000 will be purchased with CTE Enhancement Funds
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Susan Cheu, Margaret Bdzil, Mike Appio, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the consigned Okama 7-axis, live tooling lathe is the only product that can fulfill the educational needs of the De Anza College Design and Manufacturing Technology program and is available only through one source, Gosiger West, and authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services to issue a purchase order to Gosiger West for the amount of $187,050.

PCO#120 This is a negotiated forty-five (45) calendar day compensable schedule extension and a forty-six (46) calendar day non-compensable schedule extension, totaling a 91 calendar day extension of the project for project work. The contractor agrees to release the Owner from any added general conditions and costs and all damages, whether know or unknown that arise from this project. The contractor shall meet the new final completion date of December 30, 2015 and be fully demobilized from the site, or the contractor will be assessed $5,000 per calendar day for each day the work is incomplete. Work must be satisfactorily finished and accepted by the District to release contractor from their obligation.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On February 9, 2015, the Board authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Swinerton Builders based upon the recommendation of the L-7 Renovation project contractor selection committee. The Preconstruction Services Agreement required Swinerton Builders to prequalify subcontractors, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, develop an actual Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) and develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule. On April 6, 2015 the Board of Trustees approved the execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease for Phase 1 of the L-7 renovation project, which included a GMP for Phase 1, in the amount of $2,734,249. 
	 
The scope of work for Phase 1 included renovating the L-7 exterior facade; renovating the classrooms interiors; upgrading power and HVAC to the building; re-roofing, new interior and exterior painting; fire alarm upgrades; lighting upgrades; accessibility upgrades, and miscellaneous interior upgrades as shown on the contract documents. Phase 1 of the L-7 Renovation project was funded by Measure C and is substantially complete. 
	 
For Phase 2, Swinerton Builders prequalified subcontractors, obtained competitive bids from subcontractors, developed a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) and provided its construction schedule. The GMP for Phase 2 was established based upon the DSA-submitted set of drawings and specifications. Phase 2 of the L-7 project will include: replacing the fire suppression system and connect it into the fire alarm systems; removes under-floor data and electrical cabling and replaces the raised floor system; installs new UPS systems; installs new overhead electrical and data raceways, data and power distribution, and added grounding; installs new lighting; installs new data equipment cabinets; installs limited data and fiber connections; and provides new interior finishes. 
	 
Swinerton Builders’ GMP for Phase 2 of this project is $1,773,585 and will be funded by Measure C. Upon execution of the Amendment No. 1 of the Facilities Lease, Swinerton Builders will continue with its control of the site to commence with Phase 2 work. Substantial Completion of the work is scheduled to be completed by June 30, 2016.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steven Kitchen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to sign Amendment No. 1 to the Facilities Lease with Swinerton Builders and to accept a GMP in the amount of $1,773,585 for Phase 2 of the L-7 Renovation project at De Anza College.
